2oEkoQtxMv-kS8W0RvG8tw.text: Unfortunately, this place is completely not the place for you if you have any desire to modify a dish, have any sort of allergy, want a simple bowl of rice on the side or need any sort of easy accommodation. On the plus side, the two things I could eat were good...

eVBLAXkyhF7urmIZFoSVhQ.text: I admit, when I started reading the menu, I was intimidated. Nothing on the menu was familiar. There was no comfort of knowing what any of the dishes might look like.  What's wonderful about Nobuo is that they offer a menu of interesting items that you may not find elsewhere. Their food is best enjoyed with a group of close friends that are cool about sharing food.   My water glass never went empty and my tummy got plenty full.  Chef Fukada even stopped by our table to say hello, extra star for that.

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. soft shell crab sandwich

yRfYR5mApACexezPW16pdQ.text: Recently went for a birthday lunch with friends and found the service to be very slow.   The place was empty except for 3 tables.  Menu was very interesting and very food, but the portion were very small and pricey.  Would not hurry back.

KH1Ms-YWhVT98a_WsA7bZw.text: My lackluster review is based mostly on staff interaction as well as lunch.  I came in right as the restaurant opened and they were shamefully unprepared. The server/host looked like he had just finished taking a huge bong rip (whatever dude, if you need it) and was SHOCKED to see someone walk into the restaurant. SHOCKED. Sorrrrryyyyy you said you were open? There was also an issue with what I ordered, the food wasn't in or ready yet. Again - if you're open, be open. If not, open a half hour later.  The pork buns were great, very good. The decor was very cool. In a little bit of a weirddddddd place? But I dig it.

QL_X3tsoeDwR4DWYBN_Xow.text: Came here with a coworker on a recent trip to Phoenix. Cute little place in an old victorian house on E. Adams acoss from my one of my favorite places in Phoenix, Pizza Bianco.  It's a japanese cuisine with a small plates style menu. We ended up splitting about 6 small plates. My favorites were: Seabass & Mushrooms - baked in parchment, garlic-butter, sake, soy Soft shell crab sandwiches Yellowtail Ceviche - miyoga , sesame seed, shredded taro  Everything we had was delicious (though I sat out on the Pork Buns, too full at that point though I heard they were delicious).  I had 2 very nice glasses of a pinot to accompany the meal.  All in all, a very nice experience. Quaint, quiet ambience, though we were the only two customers there for an 8:30pm dinner reservation. While it was a Wednesday night, it's still a wonder that the place was empty.

0K4GvKKwDUGptvwgTWfCBw.text: Such a cute, quaint little place!  It's a house converted into a restaurant in Heritage Square in downtown Phoenix.  It's a great place to come for tea.  However, there are very few food items on the menu and they are mostly appetizers.  I would not come here for a meal but rather some tea and a snack.

IsdeqLZpq_9dXlrqk68QKw.text: have been there for both lunch and dinner, i would give it a 4.5 star, but since it is a fairly special place i am giving it a 5 now.  The lunch was probably the best you can imagine. Great food, good service, and very reasonable price. All the dishes there taste so good, i don't even know what to recommend, basically just try anything you feel like.  However, dinner was way more expensive. We only ordered three small dishes and that was already 60 dollars... Sashimi was just so so. The other two dishes are better but still a little bit pricey for what they are .  So basically i would recommend it for lunch, and try out their non-traditional japanese food, you will be surprised.

EEITIHfk-1q2rnFssLMNNA.text: I joined a friend of Mine here for Her birthday dinner. Reservations had to be made so I assumed it was pretty upscale. Especially after reading the reviews. The Pro's: atmosphere is simple yet intimate and sophisticated.  Server was knowledgeable over the entire menu. Including the wine list. Food was heavenly! Felt like I was showcasing dishes from Iron Chef or some other food challenge show. Like a food orgasm of flavor and textures in My mouth!!! The Con's; small portions & extremely pricey!We easily spent $70 per person. Parking was confusing! No street parking, parking garage around the block. Teeter House will validate so make sure to take your ticket with you. Food prep time was a bit long (over 30 minutes). Overall GREAT upscale dining experience, Great for a nice date nite. Just make sure your date has some class & some cash....

g7O9BrA3SmwqYAQS6oTYpw.text: Came here for Restaurant Week with my parents.  We were going to Symphony Hall afterwards and this place was nearby.  Its directly across the way from Pizzeria Bianco and next door to Rose & Crown in the Heritage Square area.  When you walk up, you immediately feel you're walking into the early 1900s as this building has maintained its character throughout the years.  You wouldn't think it'd make sense to put a Japanese restaurant here, but then again this is no ordinary Japanese restaurant.  I'd heard Nobuo Fakoda had a James Beard award to his credit so that (and the solid Yelp reviews) got us the door.  To start the evening I had the pork bun.  Its basically pork belly wrapped in a rice bun with herbs and a pickle.  Small, simple, but bursting with flavor.  Great way to start things off.  For the main course they had bento boxes (basically an assortment of greatest hits in a box).  I chose the seafood bento box which included tuna, salmon, and various other fishes I couldn't recognize.  Included was sticky rice, wasabi, soy sauce, and greens.  Pretty good stuff, though the pieces of fish were perhaps a little big to hold with chop sticks.  For dessert, I got the Arai pastries which included a piece of chocolate cake and what tasted almost like coffee cake.  Both were surprisingly light and airy, and were pretty good, though nothing special in my opinion.  I didn't get any drinks so my bill for the restaurant week meal (including tip) was $50.  I was satisfied and somewhat full, but not uncomfortably so at all.  Overall, a pretty cool restaurant in a really unique location.  Not all of the dishes wowed me, but they did a pretty decent job showcasing their greatest hits during Restaurant Week.  This is definitely a splurge restaurant on a normal night and some of the items, while expensive, won't necessarily fill you up.  The service we got was okay.  The host was a little standoffish and the waitress wasn't completely informed on some of the non-Restaurant Week items so that might be an area for them to address.  Bottomline, if you've got the money and a craving for a Japanese restaurant that goes outside the box, this place will do the job.

GJX_kEZ2wKOO6olG9SpzDw.text: This is a very "homie" type of place. Little plates but very expensive if you want to feel full. It's a family sharing type of place. One time is probably enough. The place itself is very small but the best dishes on the menu are the hamachi, soft shell, lamb, foie gras. If you're willing to pay about 400$ for the whole menu to split then this is the place to go. Otherwise I feel this is very expensive and not enough meal for your buck.

neoW2i1IZxbxBLUSrLw3Xg.text: So let me start off by saying that when I looked at this place, I looked at it through they eyes of a chef from the SF Bay... I wondered if a 28 Zagat rating in Phoenix is the same as in SF... I can't speak for other places, but in the case of Nobuo at Teeter House, it absolutely does! I would put that food up against anything I've eaten out here, or could make myself  I was there with my girlfriend for her birthday... we arrived a few minutes early for our reservation which wasn't a problem for them (which is always nice) Our waiter was super friendly and conscious but not overbearing... he was great  We got a couple of cocktails (both were really good) with our starters... let me back up... we got starters, small bites and hot dishes...   We got kimchi, the watermelon salad and nasu... I love kimchi, i could eat it with every meal... but theirs was great... the watermelon salad was exceptional... the nasu was something special... after the first round of starters we ordered a bottle of wine and got down to our our meal...   we started with the grapefruit hamachi and the shiromi carpaccio... i am not a fan of truffle oil... usually people overdo it because "oh my god, it's truffle oil... it's so good!!!" they used enough on the hamachi that it would be there, but not there... just enough to accent the dish. I do however love yuzu and they used it brilliantly on the carpaccio...   next we ordered entrees... the warm duck salad and karei karaage. The warm duck salad was simple, but lovely... grilled escarole is really nice when it's charred, but not cooked to much... not everyone likes the bitterness of the leaf, but it was a nice accompaniment to the duck and the sauce... the karei karaage was something else... first, it looked really cool... they fried the bones and made a basket to hold the pieces of fish... nice touch... also you can eat the bones, which were great, and the sauce was cool and refreshing.   after this we were still hungry... we overheard "oysters and uni" so we asked our waiter about the oysters and got those, along with tako and tomato. The oysters were along the same lines as all the other food... the octopus however, was a complete departure from the rest of the menu... which was not a bad thing at all  octopus, tomato and mozzarella belongs somewhere from Spain to Greece (just change the kind of cheese)... having it at an Japanese influenced restaurant was a pleasant surprise, and shows the outlook of the chef... that it doesn't matter where the food comes from, if it works, use it! Yay!  I can not say enough good things about Nobuo at Teeter House. I hope I am lucky enough to someday own a restaurant like this.  Thank you! Thank you!

zhTXTKOTDropur5LVYaZvw.text: Interesting and unique parings make the food not only tasty but visually appealing.  I would definitely return here.

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States

pnaA5oLvCz1QHnnptEh2kg.text: Great food and friendly service... I am a soft shell crab fanatic the one I had last night is by far one of the best ones I ever had.   Give it a try you won't be disappointed!

w7L5ouSOAx2lwsZQ0gK4hw.text: Let me first start off by saying I was skeptical.  I had no idea what to expect and after reading a ton of reviews, we thought we would give it a shot.   Located in an old converted home in Heritage Park right across from Pizzeria Bianco the place is small and intimate and just an experience in and of itself.  Now for the food.  Where do I begin?  Tapas (small plates) style, and community (share) the experience is in ordering from each section of the menu.  We started with the Kimci and Nasu.  The Kimci is a Napa cabbage cold plate that will rock your world; a little sweet, a little spicy it was a great way to start.    The Nasu is an eggplant with a bacon marinade of sorts on top and while I am describing it poorly it was truly delishous.  Amazing!!  Next was the Yellowtail Ceviche.  This WAS OUT OF THIS F'ING WORLD.  Inexplicable but so, SO GOOD.    Next was 2 off the menu plates, chicken and Wagyu beef short ribs.  The ONLY REASON this place does not get 5 stars is 2 of the 3 different types of chicken were mediocre.  The wasabi grilled chicken was pure wasabi on grilled chicken.    The 2nd was a panko fried chicken, which was moist and delishous but nothing amazing, HOWEVER the 3rd chicken was an orange peel fried chicken that way just so good beyond words.  Lastly, the Wagyu beef short ribs were so so so amazing, I mean, I never wanted the taste to leave my mouth.  The service, very good Juan (our server) was very attentive and very helpful as it was our first time there...but it most definitely will not be our last...oh and THEY VALIDATE FOR PARKING ;)

agq38d34K54LssaNLYpwUw.text: I have been here twice, and both times were amazing.   The atmosphere is simple yet polished. You could enjoy it dressed down or up. The restaurant feels like it wants you to just enjoy the meal.   The service was fantastic. Everyone was attentive and knew the menu.   Most importantly, the food is exquisite and worth every penny. Yes, it can be expensive and the portions small, but every dish highlights the flavors and textures of all its ingredients, which are fresh and sometimes local.   If you're worried about cost, go with a friend and split it down the middle. You'll have more bang for your buck and still walk out satiated.   Hands down the best Japanese in Phoenix.

vI5d862Ek0OE_ly4iEvOPQ.text: All the food here is wonderful. Tastes amazing! I went with my best friend and we split everything. I went there December 5, 2010 and we had:  Japanese Chips - A very yummy snack made with fingerling potatoes.  Ebi Salad - Very refreshing! I could eat this for lunch everyday.  Duck Breast Salad - I have never been a huge duck fan, but oh my god, this duck tasted like steak. Its amazing!!  Okonomiyaki - Very good and filling. The japanese mayo is great too!  Shiromi Carpaccio - This dish was excellent! Make sure to get extra bread, because the oil and seasonings are so amazing. You will want to savor every bite!  and for my drink, you must try the Devils Haircut! I could have drank quite a few of these! I cant wait to go back on my next Arizona trip!

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. We ate the duck salad so fast, but I managed to take a pic of what was left :) Its so good!
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Shiromi Carpaccio
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Japanese Chips

hNC9yfL-x9N3Cg2PTL40SA.text: This is my favorite restaurant in Arizona. Fabulous food is masterfully prepared.  I love everything about Nobuo; the quirky little rooms, the location and  the vibe- and of course the food, the food, the food.

nPyMO9Kq9EiwN0wAvbS80Q.text: Nice location in heritage park.  Beautiful home turned into nice restaurants.  A brief look at the menu had us pulling up our yelp app for some information on what to get.  Unfortunately the pork belly buns everyone was raving about was not available.  We chose: Grapefruit and Hamachi, Big-Eye Tuna Tataki, Seabass and Mushroom, and finally the pork belly and rice.  Every dish was succulent.  They were on the small side, and I understand this is how tapas works, so you can share it, but it still left me feeling just a tad hungry.  Still the food was amazing and the flavors simply perfect.

VDCXnuoOsz-0XdK1JNQB1A.text: Very nice experience, the Pork Belly Buns are great and the warm duck salad was everything a salad should be: good,complex and varied texture. This was our first visit and it certainly won't be our last. The restaurant is housed in a lovely older home that was moved to this location ( Heritage Square, in downtown Phoenix) to remind us what the city was like in the past. Lots of small rooms makes it feel like a private dining experience.

IwCV5JI7xQ_h3vabXLAZ_w.text: Nobuo offers modern Japanese menu with interesting items. The atmosphere is amazing and perfect for dating! Just keep in mind that you should book a table in advance because it gets booked quickly and it's usually full! We tried several dishes including the pork belly served over rice and banana leaf which was my most favorite item! It was very tender and melted in mouth.i would highly suggest that! We tried the chicken which was undercook unfortunately but the chef took it back to the kitchen and served us a new plate. That was a little disappointing because my expectation of fine dining restaurants is higher especially a place like here that don't have that offers kind of personalized dining experience. Overall it was a good experience in Phoenix area and I would suggest you to give a try at least for once!

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States

0TxnHXrdF1LgJk1RhXgWPg.text: There's something about high-end Japanese restaurants- they take it to a totally new level. My once favorite Japanese restaurant (now closed) called Shinbay has some sort of relation to the chef at Nobuo. I'm not sure the exact relationship, but the quality and innovation is comparable (ambiance is totally different). My husband and I went for lunch one day. We went there for a late lunch and we were two of the six people at the restaurant. We sat at the bar and watched chef Nobuo unpack pots and pans for the dinner. It was slightly awkward, but we need to consider that we chose those seats at the end of lunch (right before dinner).   The food. Oh my gosh, the food. You could lock me in a metal box with this food and I would still give it five stars. The presentation, the combination of textures, flavors, and temperatures were spot on. Mind, officially, blow

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Warm duck salad- a must!

NphRql2244Uiu-8IiiZr5A.text: This place is in heritage square in downtown Phoenix. I went for lunch and I gotta say I was honestly overwhelmed with this place. I got the Dave's chicken katsu with curry and rice it was good and delicious. My girlfriend got the pork belly buns also delicious. Definitely recommended

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States

7GFvPQG7Kyf6zre-qxpd5Q.text: For a fancy Japanese restaurant, it's disappointing that they don't offer sushi during lunch. Why?  They served bento boxes for lunch and it was okay. Nothing to rave about.  Maybe I'll give this place another try for dinner.  The ambiance is nice. It's a converted old Victorian home turned into an Asian eatery. It's a little tight and the tables are way too close. You hear people's conversations and it gets pretty annoying.

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States

wNwNynC7MJFk334T2HEcBQ.text: The seafood here is to die for! They brought out each dish one at a time for our table and the presentation of the food was just as amazing as I expected it to be. Another plus was that they were very tentative to our table and brought out all of our food in a timely manner. I highly recommend trying out some of their cocktails as well, so delicious! I will for sure be back here soon.

cpvWDnxVB93joDGWm0Cixw.text: The Arizona Restaurant week menu was a great deal and the food was absolutely delicious. I love that we got to try many of their staple items on their menu in a bento box! Definitely the highlight of our restaurant week experiences. The ambiance is unique as it basically feels like you're eating in someone's house in Heritage Square. They may want to rethink the hostess stand and the seating around it. We were sat at one of the two tables when you first walk in and were distracted by the conversations at the hostess stand. It wouldn't normally be terrible, but at one point an argument broke out between the wait staff about the reservations. This included loud yelling and even cussing. It was not the fine dining experience we were expecting.

fsJGDPrgRwckflyMbEG_gQ.text: I took my son and granddaughter there for her 17th bday, she is a "foodie".  I've been in the restaurant business for over 50yrs. And was really anticipating an amazing experience. The food was good not great, but from the time we walked in the3 employees made eye contact and went back to their conversations (we had a reservation). We had to ask for another setup and another water, only 2 other tables in the restaurant. We ordered appetizers after 45 minutes all the food arrived together. Very disappointed in the lack of service.

wieMfYFVV6-9wiEssNiLOA.text: Literally the best place I've ever eaten at. Nothing compares. Food is exquisite, and of top quality. Customer service is top notch also. Easily the best dinner of my life. Went here for an anniversary with my boyfriend, and will be back for sure. We both fell in love with the food--fell in love with the whole place. Worth every single penny.

YlTUJrysUJCg1SWqwAxRQw.text: If I could I would give Nobuo 10 stars... 20 stars... Heck, all the stars! I have been wanting to try this place since I relocated to Phoenix several years back but I wasn't willing to go here unless I, A.) Went with a major foodie like myself  B.) Had the opportunity to try the omkase   So when such unicorn stars aligned I was so excited to check this place off of my list (finally!).   Now, I have like you (presumably) if your reading this, have always heard such amazing things about Nobou and his James Beard Winning restaurant. But I, if we are going full disclosure on things wasn't expecting it to be this damn good! From the first bite to the last sip of sake, Nobou and his culinary genius just wowed me. The food was simple, yet so well thought out, and to put the horn on the unicorn Nobou was charming and funny and I left wanting him to be my new bff.    Now, I can't sit here and tell you about every single bite I ate, but what I can tell you is that you are simply doing yourself a disservice by not hurrying and making the next possible reservation to experience what I did.   What can I tell you? I left with wisdom, I left drinking a ridiculously good bottle of Arizona Sake (seriously, it was delicious!), I may have gotten talked into eating an eyeball from a fish and I left eating what will be known as one of the best meals I have ever had.   So read my lips errrr my text... The hype is no hype, this shiz is real deal.

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States

Fxt98A2xYSdpnoo3I5rkRA.text: The daily sashimi is outstanding. I did an ala carte ordering of cold and warm dishes. Everything tastes great and the presentation was extravagant. Portions are small so beware. The staff were informative but not overly friendly or helpful. They were unwilling to do something special for an anniversary and the layout inside the restaurant is crowded and cumbersome.

eGxd-VY4UHh0DIKazA8TNg.text: I came here on a lunch date with a friend a couple of months back. I work just about 10 mins from here, so I figured I'd give it a try.  This place is SO cute. Besides the charming exterior that grabs your attention as you walk in, the interior is even better! It's small and intimate. I had the chicken katsu curry, and I have to admit that it's the best katsu curry I've had all over Phoenix (and I've been on the hunt for about a year now)! I came right before they closed between the lunch and dinner times, so it was empty. The service was still flawless and my friend and I enjoyed our time here.  It is a bit pricy, and I wish the lunch menu had more options.  We parked on the garage and validated our ticket for dining here. Overall, I'd come back again for a cute date night.

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Front entrance of the restaurant. So charming.

q8m2fTfjYtLurAIDeadp0A.text: Nobuo provided an authentic experience between the setting and the food. There wasn't a bad dish on the whole menu even when they change it, everything blends so well together and the combination makes sense. Definitely a treat to have if you're ever passing by downtown Phoenix and love sushi.

Qzp33ddYPleIZekSXFAcKg.text: Well, it was pretentious. Kind of pricey for what it was.  Service was wonderful. Building is beautiful.  Loved the ambiance. Not a bad restaurant but maybe our expectations were too high.

GPp6sLhXNTN6IolbxQ1QHw.text: Service seems oblivious, pretentious without the quality to back it up. Called ahead for certain dishes that were no longer on the menu when we arrived for our reservation. Treated poorly and actually left the restaurant mid meal to go across the street. Level of pretension is absurd. Management is haphazard, not organized, and lacks attention to detail. Not worth it - go to Hana or another sushi restaurant nearby for same quality of food, less attitude.

4M8I4lKedbH6IVDe8608uQ.text: We enjoyed a late lunch at Nobuo on Sunday afternoon. I had been here before but hadn't had the opportunity to actually eat a meal because they were pretty busy. Was super excited to come and try the summer bento box lunch special they were offering.   Pro's ~Loved that there were many options to choose from for the bento box. I picked the Grilled Mackerel, Grilled Tofu, and Braised Pork Belly Bun. I was bummed that I didn't get to try the short rib salad but because they were out but we did also come 45 minutes before lunch was ending so that makes sense. ~Everything was super tasty and was just the right portion size, I left feeling full and was happy that I got to taste a little bit of everything. ~ Love the quaint little house and the intimate space. It was perfect for an afternoon date and we will definitely be coming back for dinner. They played great music too! ~Our drinks were never empty, our server did a great job at always making sure we were taken care of.  Con's  ~Parking..but let's be honest parking downtown is just a pain in the a** anyways. You can get validated if you park in the lot that is just west of the restaurant and walk thru the parking garage. I made the mistake of parking in the parking structure that was to the south of the science center. Make sure to take your ticket in with you while you dine so they can validate you  ~Price..I think the price is in line with the quality of food you get but I would like to see it maybe include the beverage as well at least for the lunch special.  We will definitely be coming back to have dinner for sure!

9EC-9oi2jE-uHkb0vzRbwA.text: Located at the heritage square, I came here for a quick appetizer and really want to come back for a full dinner someday, hopefully soon.  I had an event near by but since my time was limited and I didn't have time to stop to eat before arriving, when I saw this place I walked in. I mentioned I only have 25 mins but they happily welcomed in and made some recommendations on food for a quick meal. It was a bit early for dinner time and I had a late lunch that day, so I just ordered salad.  Warm duck salad was not what I thought it was going to be as a salad. It exceeded my imagination and I truly enjoyed my warm duck salad. I think I had a certain image for salad and what they served here was outside the box. Perfect little appetizer, just right portion size for what I needed at that time.  Lovely ambiance, loved nice small touch to the decor, perfect for a date night, I just need to find one, lol.

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Entrance
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Warm duck salad

zzDvKTMsryrLeVGI2A6nuw.text: I am disappointed to leave such a poor review of this restaurant, after how excited my (6-person) family was to support and experience the work of this James Beard Award-winning chef featured in the Phoenix Film Festival documentary, "Kakehashi: Portrait of Chef Nobuo Fukuda."    In full disclosure, we visited Nobuo during Restaurant Week, so we did not have the benefit of trying items on the full menu.  Still, quality should not be shirked when your customers are paying $44 for vegetables, a bento box (choice of beef or seafood), and dessert.  I will say the cocktails hit the spot. I can see myself enjoying one on their quaint deck on a warm summer evening.  This said...the service was mediocre and unmemorable.  We felt like the staff barely acknowledged our presence.  Our food was well-timed but equally underwhelming.  The bento box was beautifully plated.  Included was some white rice and salad dressed with the traditional ginger dressing.  However, the entrees were cold aside from the mushroom dish which I didn't care for.  The fried, soft-shell crab was my favorite with mango slaw - but room temperature.  The seared tuna was also a little tough when it should melt in your mouth.  The desserts were GROSS - and I found what looked like a ball of thread or some other thready object in my brother's pudding.  We left it right on top of the plate, hoping someone might see it as we left.    My mother in particular was excited to pay tribute to Chef Nobuo and, given the slow Saturday evening, thought he might greet his patrons at some point during the meal, as is typically expected in fine dining - at least a nice touch.  Instead she caught him standing behind the counter, texting, seemingly without awareness that there was a dinner service flowing around him.  She stood by for a few seconds hoping to get his attention but he ignored her.    I very much hope this was an off night for Chef Nobuo and his staff - I hate to think the quality of the food and service was compromised just because he (voluntarily) turned less of a profit.  Unfortunately for this family of six, first impressions are everything and the exorbitant expense doesn't really justify a second chance.  :-(

s8sA3zbKtFEsB1gTRxcdjg.text: Such a great experience! Located in a little converted house across from Pizzeria Bianco.  Delicious, well prepared dishes to share, which makes it a fun, interactive night.  My kids loved the lamb chops, and the hamachi, ceviche, and Sea Bass special we're delicious! Very intimate setting with a tiny, quaint little bar.  The staff is very knowledge and sweet. Can't wait to go back!

kfLQWjxBcnppbB4HboBggw.text: Such a beautiful experience. Highly recommend. The area. The building. The ambiance. The service. The food. All of it. Unfussy. Elegant. Delicious. Just beautiful. Be sure to bring cash with you for parking at valet or to park at the garage in case a game is going on. But parking either way is easy.

VxpLyFqF6_srKuKlNnb_OQ.text: Enjoyed the following... watermelon & goat cheese salad, duck salad - amazing and tofu chocolate mousse and orange almond fritters. Amazing!!!

IJTuV8_2eqF8Ilr4y8vCcg.text: Great lunch dining experience.  Liked everything we had Grapefruit and halibut - amazing Tofu salad - refreshing Soft shell crab sandwich - tasty Pork belly bun - delicious  Great service as well. Will return

ehH5OCLp9nhZAiLlJyyB6Q.text: A little gem in Phoenix.  Beard award winner chef Nobuo puts up a tapas-style show a flavors, ingredients and presentations in an unpretentious environment.  All the dishes we tried were great, including the foias gras, hamachi, squash blossom tempura, eggplant and miso cod. This one's a keeper!

9TCyB8_d-h9KEsIAXyuZsQ.text: Had dinner here on June 10.  The food was amazing as we had allowed the chef to prepare a 7 course meal as he determined.  The staff and chef were excellent and we had a very enjoyable meal.  The only down side I felt was that the prices seemed very high to me, but I am not familiar with Japanese restaurants so perhaps that perception is merely due to my lack of experience.  We will certainly return for dinner again.

eAILyXYFv0dqDesvGNoAOQ.text: Are you serious ?? This is not even a 2 star "Japanese" Tea House...   Starter : Tako Age ,  How's that special? It's just a mouthful of fried flour.  Cold dish: Yellow Tail Ceviche , This is just Ok as the grapefruit juice is too sour that cover the freshness of the fish .   Main Course: Washyugyu ... OMG... how you can make these tasty beef not even juicy at all...  Or is it just a new way people like wasting $ here?   My bill comes to ~$ 60 and, to be honest, why don't just go to ShinBay for a 3 courses meal?  Don't even put Japanese food on your category. THIS IS NOT JAPANESE FOOD AT ALL.   AVOID, YELP is unreal for this restaurant

BCqw3Fh1-pNxLqXK4vD56A.text: Lindsey here, reporting to you live from a self-induced food coma thanks to the delicious cuisine courtesy of Nobuo.   Let's see...where shall I begin?   I finally had the perfect excuse to check a visit to Nobuo off my list: Yelp Eats! So tonight, fellow yelpers and myself sat in the adorable Teeter house and dined on master cuisine. I began with the refreshing watermelon and goat cheese salad. It was like a never-ending bowl of melon that was perfectly matched with creamy goat cheese.   As our table laughed and chatted about everything under the sun, I ordered another appetizer: the teeter tots. Holy tots Napoleon! At first glance, the idea of tofu teeter tots didn't appeal to me too much, but I'm a sucker for anything fried so I decided to give it a try. Well, the fried tofu was smothered with mouthwatering sweet sauce and after one taste, the rest of the table ordered a dish for themselves! In fact, they were so good, Dave N ate them again for dessert! Even if you aren't a tofu lover, I still suggest you get them. They are heavenly.   Now let's move on to the entrees. I had half of the soft shell crab sandwich dish and half of the pork belly steamed buns. Both were crafted perfectly. The pork belly steamed buns come on a rice bun and the pork and sauce are complimented perfectly within the bun. The soft shell crab sandwich comes with two small sandwiches. The crab melts in your mouth and the sauce is the perfect addition. If you go with a friend, order both dishes and share!   We ended the night with a sweet goodbye known as the orange almond fritters. Imagine four donut holes with ice cream on top and covered in a thick Carmel/orange-like sauce. Perfecto!   The atmosphere here is wonderful as well because it's situated in the historic Teeter house. In fact, tonight I learned that this house was occupied by the owner until her death in the 1970s. It's truly a piece of Phoenix history and worth stopping into even if it's just to see the house. But do yourself a favor and stay to dine as well!

hqOwQ5rZIasI3dnvXC-YVQ.text: I love Nobuo usually.  But we had such a terrible experience at our meal before attending the Nutcracker that I have to keep others informed.   It could have been an off night.  I really hope so (I really want to go back), but each portion of our meal was served individually, took forever, we had to eat our meals separately, and they broke our water glass and it spilled all over the table.  They offered free dessert but we had to get a move on as the ballet started at 7.  We assumed arriving with a reservation right away at 5:30 would be fine and it was quiet at the restaurant.  Clearly it didn't make a difference.  We'll probably go somewhere else in the future for special occasions and hopefully brave another dining adventure here when we're not trying to get somewhere else.  (though I'm still upset over our mains coming out at different times, after the other, with huge breaks of time between; it was ridiculous).

Yf3i5q1MTyjmRkJtx9V6xQ.text: If cost is of no concern, and you don't mind spending $4 per bite, then this restaurant is the one for you.  The food (or more correctly, each bite) tasted phenomenal, and you can see and taste the attention to detail and the creativity in each dish.  So to be fair, you're not just throwing away your hard-earned money.  I just wish there was more on each plate to enjoy and savor.    Like I said, the whole meal was excellent, and the venue and ambiance are both extraordinary (old bungalow converted to restaurant, so you're eating in small rooms that hold 4 or 5 tables each at most).  Very intimate, cozy, and relaxed.  All of the cold courses were great - hamachi with grapefruit, grilled octopus with tomato and mozzarella (it somehow all worked together), and the oysters with uni.     Ordered several warm dishes, with the warm duck salad surprisingly being the best dish of the whole night.  I was a little hesitant to order the salad because it just sounded a little weird, but it's absolutely a must-get.  The grilled greens imparted a smoky flavor to the dish, and paired with the rare duck, this salad has to be one of the best dishes in the city.  The sea bass cooked in parchment was just okay, and only had 5 or 6 forkfuls at most.  There were also a couple of Japanese single-malt whiskeys that were pretty decent.  Do you know which country produces the most single-malts in the world after the #1 producer (Scotland)?    Nice upscale experience, nice atmosphere, great delectable dishes, and great drinks, but very expensive.  Is it worth it?  Sometimes you just can't put a price on awesome food served in unique ways in a unique environment.  All I know is, we scooted on over to Bianco right after paying the bill and polished off a couple of pies each.  Two great restaurants right next to each other, with each chef being skilled and masterful in his own right, but only one leaving me fully satisfied.

wEsfgumNG0FHHkCnY01ReA.text: Meh.   Ambiance was drab. Server was cold and im pretty sure didnt smile once. Food wasnt great and kinda overpriced for what it was. Cocktails were ok.   Coming from new york, ive had better top to bottom. Probably wont go again. But id suggest it to someone if they wanted to experiment.   Id recommend the kimchi though. That was super tasty.

ilJRVLfFP0fUqACVn429pA.text: Went for my Birthday what a great time . Food was so different the lamb was perfect . Cant wait to go back .Little pricey but worth it . A must try in Phoenix .

9XOoDSuj1auboNGLoISeMA.text: Best and most interesting sushi ever. The selection of Sake is incredible. First time I have had it chilled and served like wine. The place is expensive, but worth it. Do not be afraid to try something unique.

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States

TfzMWefnsv2RKs6VEC3n6w.text: Get the yellow tail ceviche. DELICIOUS. Beautiful old brick home, wonderful atmosphere. Service is always great, food is out in a timely manner and they're friendly and attentive. I recommend making a reservation first, as it is a smaller building with a limited amount of seating. A reservation will assure that you have a smooth evening. Love it!

J-SXOVIrF7w-Lc4muNGadw.text: IMPORTANT:  You will spend $50 per person here, and walk away slightly full, NOT stuffed.  You need to get that through your head to enjoy this place.  I dropped $110 including tip, and no alchoholic drinks between my wife and myself (just one iced tea).  We had 9 dishes, including 3 appetizer, 3 "entree" and 3 small deserts.     We ate everything on every plate... and at the end of the night, we still could have easily eaten more.    So this isn't a place you go to "fill up."  Budget $50 easy per person, then when you get there, SPEND it all on dishes.  And have absolutely no regrets, because you've prepared yourself.  And then be prepared to be blown away by the tastes and presentation of each dish.  Each dish comes out for the table one at a time, maybe 10 minutes apart.  Each will inevitably be deemed "delicious" by all a the table.  Each will likely be the best version of whatever it is, you've tasted for a long while... maybe ever.  Seabass and Mushrooms in white paper.   I've never had fish that tasted like that... and the mushrooms blew my mind.  Tofu fried tater tots... absolutely delicious.    Soft shelled crab sliders... amazing.  Maybe my favorite.  The pork in the buns was the most "normal dish", but terribly good.  It was really all very outstanding.  Perhaps one of the best "date" restaurants if you want to blow some money, that I've found in Phoenix.  Of course I couldn't have afforded it when I was dating... so small problem.  But if dropping $100 on amazing tastes and flavors and not at least being thoroughly full at the end bothers you, don't go, as it will be an exercise in frustration.  No point being stressed about the money you are spending.  There is a place for restaurants like this.  And they are terrific.  But you have to get your mind straight.  I will be back.  Sorry if I come across as a cheap bastard with expensive tastes... but... I am.  And Nobuo is worth every penny.

fk6Ocu7UO3f2NaqIEgh3vg.text: Great food and charming ambience!  We ordered about 6 dishes for 4 people and shared. My favorite dish was the hamachi and the soft crab salad.   Expect to spend, portions are small and prices are high..... Treat yourself!

uf_EgPps3J85sK_q_ou2Hw.text: There really isn't much more to say, because you can see how awesome this place is from my original review. Or from the reviews of others.  I came in for the Yelp Eats UYE, and went to town by crushing some mad food.  On this particular night, I had the Yellowtail Sashimi, Pork Belly Steamed Buns, Soft Shell Crab Sandwich, and for dessert, another appetizer....the Teeter Tots. Yes, two entrees, and an appetizer for dessert. It was that damn good.  Don't waste time reading any more reviews. Just go. Nobuo. Now.

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Decor
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Yellowtail Sashimi
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Teeter Tots

Ia9Ss3U32sPL0DaydpzD4g.text: Nice atmosphere, trendy and the food was good.  Small portions were to be expected given this place is trying to position itself as a 5-star, famous in-house chef type restaurant.  But this is where Nobuo ultimately fails - if you want to come on at this price point and position at the top, you've got to nail it on all levels.  Service here was amateur at best and while top notch, the food wasn't as good as what you'd expect were you to go to a similar level restaurant in LA or NYC.  Nobuo is a good four star restaurant priced and positioned as a five star experience - it's good but I wouldn't go back.

HTIY6k9-Y11Rqyi8l0J_VQ.text: Wow...this is the second time I was here and it's an unbelievably wonderful place. Dishes are small but very high quality and inventive presentation. Fairly priced given how good the food is. The salmon and lamb were particularly good. The service was attentive and knowledgable.

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. House-cured salmon was great.

207KmyrJSm6nxuUziU53dg.text: Sad that it took me so long to try Nobuo. Sushi isn't my absolute favorite, but I do enjoy it - and at Nobuo, it is nothing short of incredible.  We started out with heirloom cauliflower that was on the small bite menu. It was nice and simple, roasted and served with a sesame dressing. I love that everything is Tapas style so you can try several dishes. Next was the grapefruit & hamachi - this is heaven in your mouth!!! Perfectly portioned in large spoons with avocado and white truffle ponzu oil, it was the best dish of the night.   We then went into the warm dishes, the warm duck salad. There was quite a bit of duck, served nearly rare. It was great, had some smokey elements to it because of the grilled greens. I think next time I'd opt for the seabass & mushroom - the table next to us was raving about it. Our final dish was the shiromi carpaccio which was incredible, they poured hot oil at the table over the top so it seared the meet. PERFECTION! Then a few minutes later they bring out warm focaccia so you can use the oil and seasonings to dip the bread.  Dessert was a pumpkin flan with Chinese 5-spice ice cream. The perfect end to the night. Polished off with a bottle of Sake and you've got yourself a perfect evening in a beautiful historic home turned restaurant.

1ryKhekBC9Ag7vduuTFjhQ.text: Such a wonderful experience. I have been visiting Nobuo for quite some time now and been taking my friends and colleagues along. The food is absolutely delicious... the flavors are rich, bright without being pretentious. The presentation is lovely and staff is very nice and friendly. Definitely a place to visit in Phoenix!

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Okonomiyaki.

Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Pondering menu selections...

APSsGVTFcVobOxCsLOLIFQ.text: Excellent Japanese restaurant serving entrees that are comparable, if not sometimes better, than food you can find in San Francisco's Japantown.  I was very excited to find they had okonomiyaki, and while there is only one kind of okonomiyaki that they will make, it was delicious, and actually better than okonomiyaki that I've had in San Francisco.  It was perfectly grilled, with a lot of vegetable and meat, with lots of flavor.  I also tried the steamed buns, which are the type that look more like Asian tacos rather than meat enclosed in white puffy bun, but tasted very good nonetheless.  If I am in this area, I will definitely be going here to try more items.

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Okonomiyaki

n9QDNhWamhjcqfDKX73ypQ.text: Located in downtown phoenix this restaurant looks like a cozy, quaint and historic house. The food is a wonderful change from typical cuisine. Everything I tried was delicious and authentic. It is tapas style and the dishes are light, quality over quantity, so I wouldn't recommend this place when one is starving and expecting a feast. Pricey for the amount of food but it is worth it for the experience and flavors.

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Lamb shanks. Absolute favorite dish I tried.
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Shrimp with the heads on!
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States

i4x4ai-tE9_8qLax5O70Eg.text: Dropped into Nobuo before a show we attended at the Science Center. I had always heard good things but didn't know quite what to expect! On our server's recommendation we ordered two cold dishes and three hot dishes, which they then coursed out for us in the manner they best saw fit.   Everything was delicious and you could tell that every single element was very carefully chosen and crafted. While we didn't have a single bad dish, I did slightly prefer the cold options. The Hassun mixed vegetable appetizer was a favorite - I love that you get an omakase selection of different preparations.   The house itself is small, but feels full of history. It really is quite quaint and an intimate dining experience. Very unique.   Overall, while on the pricier side, we felt that we got our money's worth. We definitely hope to be back again!

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Chocolate cake with green tea icing and grilled peach compote
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Beef short ribs
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Chicken Nanban

PwICIVV7204rA05FK7jsHg.text: My all time favorite Japanese restaurant in the Valley. Love practically everything that I can eat on their menu. Highly suggest at least one trip here. Esp for the dinner or Omakase.  I wouldn't recommend going during the restaurant weeks though. The menu and the presentation were spot on during our recent trip to the restaurant. Loved how they served in amazing bento boxes however the food was cold and even the salad and accompaniments were very soggy. It didn't feel like the usual Nobu standard that we have come to expect esp. since the soggy items and cold miso cod made me cringe and feel as if the food wasn't freshly made.

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States

M3VRLVzxYbBJb4DE8NceLw.text: Delicious plates but small portions. I would not go with a group bigger than 4. We had ordered 9 plates for our group of 5 but it had not been enough. That said, most of plates were fantastic and beautiful.  The menu is divided into two sections - cold and warm. Cold consists of a lot of raw fish (not sushi). Favorites include oysters and grapefruit and hamachi. I had really wanted uni with oysters but they were unavailable at the time. The grapefruit went really well with the fish. I did not like the house salmon because it had parmesan cheese on top and was very strange tasting The warm plates were pretty good. The black cod was definitely the standout dish. Perfectly cooked and so delicious.  I would come again but only with one other person.

DfjMIB_YhdRlelqvwEqHiQ.text: This was our favorite meal on our trip to the Tempe/Phoenix area. Great drinks and even better food. Everything is so fresh and not too fussed with, so you really taste all of the natural flavors. My favorites were the grapefruit and hamachi and the tempura squash blossoms filled with goat cheese. Do consider this place if you're looking for a special occasion type of meal or just want to try some elevated Japanese cuisine. Reservations are recommended.

bi5kOgZ7JNrOxf3dp6lDBA.text: A friend and I went in for drinks. We were going to order alcoholic drinks. Was not going to order dinner. There was a storm outside and we were seeking shelter. We were told no. That they would not serve drinks without a meal. There were no other patrons in the restaurant. We left. We will not return. They had the opportunity to have paying customers sitting at the bar area. They chose not to do so.

jYnNWd6wD4J1XEeVWXg66A.text: Great little place to grab a quick lunch! Service was great, super friendly and even called to make sure I knew how to get to parking. Parking is validated at the garage which is nice. Dishes were all good, we got the hamachi, salmon, duck salad, and bao. Good for sharing. Would stop in again if I'm in the area.

vs_jnRGQcNgKImPdsrGgZQ.text: 5 stars all the way! This place is amazing. All of the flavors go together so well and you get to try a little of a lot with their tapas style concept. My favorite dish was the chicken. But honestly you can't go wrong here.

veIQOcru1SOXGKsi81xA2w.text: We just ate at Nobuo last night - it was a Ramen tasting menu plus add ons - everything we ate was fabulous - so much so, we added on every plate except for one!  Our server was very knowledgeable and helpful in selecting a sake, new to us, but which we really enjoyed.  This was our first time, but we will go back for sure!

fY9gPJhKJjiEOiso0i5OCA.text: My daughter and I went to the the Matsuri Festival and we ran across Nobuo at Teeter House. An Asian-style tea house in downtown Heritage Square. Chef Nobuo Fukuda's Zagat award winning vision of a modern Japanese Izakaya restaurant. We enjoyed 3 entrees Okonomiyaki,  grilled short rib salad, and a soft shell crab sandwich with Asian slaw all of them were delicious Nobu was a wonderful experience.

C_8JosZsi7XDpGa0Qv4wcA.text: I can't believe how great that meal was. It was one of the single best meals I've had in Arizona. I had wanted to have dinner here for a year. Finally I too know what all the fuss is about. The flavors meld together beautifully, these complex flavors with layers balance perfectly in every dish. Multiple times I had to close my eyes to better taste the food. Service is great. All of the wait staff seem to genuinely care about the food they are serving you and wanting you to understand it and enjoy. The black cod might have been the beat single bite of food I've had in a long time. The grapefruit and hamachi, which we started with, was so good I thought it was going to be the best thing we had. There were at least two other dishes that were as good or better, like the carpaccio, the Saikyo Yaki, the clams and mushrooms and the cod. Definitely the grapefruit hamachi (I think that's what it was but I will add comments to photos. I will post the beers also, which were fantastic amd paired well. I apologize that I do not know the names of what I ordered, I took photos of the set menu, which we did not ordered, we ordered much more and mostly hot dishes.

LTnQbYbwg3Egp2hVxQ55pg.text: A friend recommended this spot and since it was AZ Restaurant Week, we thought we'd give it a shot.  The food was pretty good, I always laugh at how we start off with the $44 restaurant Week menu and somehow our bill comes out closer to $200 for my wife and I.  While the actual Restaurant Week menu wasn't all that, we had some really amazing Foie Gras!  We may be back again for a really special occasion and maybe try some sushi.  The restaurant was packed (as I figured it would be) even though it was a week night.  Space is pretty tight to begin with so expect to be somewhat crammed in.  The staff is great, super friendly but this is definitely one of those social places where you take your time with dinner.

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Restaurant Week Desserts

Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Restaurant Week menu - Appetizers

JXtrbvlYpEWHGusVqfk_xQ.text: I have had lunch here a couple times prior and decided to try them out for dinner prior to an event at the Arizona Science Center, and I was not disappointed.  Two friends and I enjoyed an amazing 7 course, tapas style, dinning experience paired with cocktails and ShoChu.  Our waitress was very knowledgeable on the cuisine and aided us in making the best choices for our evening.  I really appreciated how the environment was modern without being pretentious.  I would definitely recommend this place if you are looking to expand your culinary flavor palate, especially if you are looking for an intimate place to have a date night.

YUn1Yd3-2Wo4w4jjSklTPg.text: Located in an old house which has been converted into a restaurant with quiet books of tables, Nobuo has an upscale version of Japanese izakaya style plates, along with fusion, modernized takes on sashimi. It's a little on the pricier side, but every bite is definitely delicious.   I had a glass of smooth junmai ginjo sake, which was served in a wine glass. I ordered three things, which was just enough for one person: a plate of assorted Japanese side dishes; black saikyo yaki with daikon and carrot slaw; and the yellowtail sashimi, which was presented in perfect bites rolled with shiso leaf. The presentation was gorgeous. The flavors were light but complex.   The food was great but felt a little odd being in an upscale setting. It's definitely a great choice for great quality Japanese food but I would not go out of my way to try this place (I'm Japanese). I'll try to come back and make a reservation for the chef's tasting and re-evaluate then.

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Plate of five seasonal veggie sides - miso eggplant, pickled radish, Shishito, snow peas, Brussels sprouts
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Yellow Tail Ceviche- love the shiso leaf
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Gindara Saikyo Yaki - black cod on a daikon and carrot slaw. This was my favorite dish - rich fish with light and vinegary veggies

AUiLyGmgaziG6EzQQyXxFQ.text: I came here for a lunch meeting and really enjoyed it! They have a pretty limited lunch menu but everything is fresh and expertly crafted.   We started with their tuna sashimi over a beet puree. It was super tasty! For my entree, I got their cold short rib noodle salad. The dressing was refreshing and the flavors fab, the portion just wasn't very big for the price. The beef was sliced super thin and there wasn't a ton of it. But hey, I had just come off of a big workout so maybe my ravenous self is being unrealistic.   Overall, cute little spot in Heritage Square with friendly service. I could see it being very romantic at night. Be sure to check the hours because I think they take a break between lunch and dinner. The reason for my 4 stars is that it is pricy for the portion sizes and there isn't a ton to choose from on the menu. For 2 of us to eat lunch it was over $60. Anywho, I'd give it another shot!

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Tuna over beet purée
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Short rib noodle salad
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Pork sandwich

dOZCzq854_tW3WTVhqhw6Q.text: The last time I came to Nobuo was about 3 years ago and I remembered being blown away. I always talk to my bf about how good the food I had was so he surprised me with a reservation for our anniversary. The last time I visited I would have rated the place 5 stars.  I have to say that although my experience last night didn't match up to the experience I had a few years ago, there were still many high notes of the dinner.   We started out with the Graptefruit Hamachi (the dish that I've dreamed about for the past 3 years) and it was great. There is so much flavor in just one bite and I love the acidity from the citrus.  (4.5 stars)  Next plate was the House-Cured Salmon. Don't order this. It's bad, not worth 18. Just a bad dish tbh because the star should be the salmon but the cheese gets in the way. It was only palatable when completely slathered with the balsamic.(1 Star)  We also ordered the nanban chicken. If you look at my uploaded photo of the dish, you can imagine how disappointing it would be to be served slightly raw chicken, especially at an establishment that prices their plates between $18-20+ each. The chef gladly sent our plate back and luckily our next dish came out short after.  When we got this plate the second time, is was fully cooked. The flavor of the chicken was great and I really loved the breading. However, I feel that the potato salad that they put on top really does a disservice to the dish as a whole because it neutralizes the flavors of everything else. Kind of like using a fire extinguisher to put out a fire. (3 stars)     The pork belly banana leaf dish was next, and it was our favorite item of the night. This dish is a MUST. The mushroom fried rice is so tasty and the pork belly just melts in your mouth. I wish we would have ordered 2 plates of this dish because it was just sooo good. (5*+ stars)  The yellowtail ceviche was our last dish of the night was recommended by the chef. This was my second favorite of the night. I love ceviche and Nobuo figured out how to make one spoonful satisfying enough to be happy. There is the citrus from the lime and a crunch from the crips they sprinkled on top. (4 stars)  Overall, if it's your first time visiting I would definitely recommend the pork belly, hamachi, and ceviche. Definitely ask questions about the menu because the servers and chef were more than happy to help us at our dinner.

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States

e4JoyvM1_1198an_5ODp1w.text: My girlfriend and I have had Nobuo on our radar for a long time now - seeing it every Restaurant Week season. We finally went to celebrate our anniversary and it definitely did not disappoint.   We both did the omakase - Call in advance and make sure you reserve for omakase. They need at least a week I think - I called a month ahead. You get to sit at a cute little bar away from the main dining area where usually 4  people enjoy omakase for the night. If you have not done a little research of your own, I believe it was around $180 per person - but I'll tell you now. It's worth every penny! Hands down the best meal I've ever had!   We started off with a really good pot of hojicha green tea. It had a wonderful roasted flavor to it and it was unlimited refills on your little tea pot (at least I think). The first course had 9 little dishes that were simply amazing. (Top row left to right) This row featured some of my favorites of the night - an amazing steamed egg with shrimp and mushrooms topped with caviar and edible gold flake (top 3 of the night). It was so simple, yet the umami was on a God-tier level.. blew my mom's steamed egg dish out of the water (sorry mom). Then there was a tofu made in-house with soy milk from Japan and fresh wasabi (my girlfriend's favorite). The last in that row was a savory egg custard that actually blew me away. I believe this was the dish he blow torched like a brulee. It was easily my favorite of the night.   (2nd row left to right) We had a local summer squash blossom tempura which was very good. This was the last batch of summer squash blossom for the season, so obviously, you'll get different vegetables depending on what time of year you go. There was also a watermelon salad drizzled with olive oil and yuzu along with goat cheese and mint. It was so good, it honestly made me question if savory watermelon was better than just plain sweet watermelon. The last dish on the row was eggplant with 2 different kinds of imported miso. I've never had miso outside of soup/ramen, so this was great. Favorite dish of the night.  (3rd row left to right) We had shoshito peppers with freshly shaved bonito flakes. Pickled radishes that were whole, but sliced so crazily, the texture was unlike anything I've ever had. And lastly, local ocra in a really good peanut (?) sauce. I actually dipped my tempura in this too.  The 2nd course was the sashimi spoons. You'll have to forgive my memory, but this was about a month ago so I could get em mixed up. To Nobuo's advice, we ate from right to left. There was a fresh oyster and uni (excellent), smoked salmon in basil oil, yellowtail with ginger, tuna, amazing amberjack in a soy sauce and olive oil sauce that reminded me of mom's cooking, octopus over tomato, marinated tuna, and mint wrapped with amberjack.   The 3rd course was the fish n chips. I'm not sure if we were told what fish, but it was steamed perfectly and had a great sauce that was a little sweet. Perfect for me since I love sweet and savory dishes. The fried fish that served as the bowl was also edible, bones and all. The 4th course was the bird cooked in some weird yoga pose. Don't let it freak you out, cause it tasted amazing. Again, I can't remember the type of bird, but Nobuo said it took 3-4 days to prepare. Well worth the wait! He carved it up for both of us to split.   5th course was the shabu shabu. First time experiencing this and it was fun! We each got our own little flame and paper filter of dashi. By now I was already pretty full, but we still got a generous portion of imported wagyu beef, sashimi, cabbage, and mushrooms to cook. This all set up our 6th course which was a soup that used our broth from the shabu shabu and had some smoked clams mixed in. Lastly, was the dessert... Beautiful to look at, better to eat. It was a white peppercorn cheesecake with berries and fresh figs. You may think white peppercorn and cheesecake don't mix, but the lady that did desserts made it work and it was delicious.   I definitely plan to go back, but it'll have to be for another special occasion. Nobuo is very friendly and you can tell that he has lot of love and passion for what he does. I'll say it again, this was the best meal I've ever had. I know there aren't many reviews out there for Nobuo's omakase, so hopefully this helps those that are interested and sways your decision.

MLXAc1SY5b9Oao8JlkZmYA.text: Wandered in here straight from the airport  with no expectations. We were so pleasantly surprised and greatly enjoyed everything. We had the sashimi fish of the day which was super fresh, shiomi carpaccio (must try) with ginger, chives, and a bit of hot oil (olive and sesame oil mix), soft shell crab again delicious, Saikyo yaki (miso black cod) super delicious, chicken namban which was also very good. Definitely recommend this place hopefully be back before we leave Phoenix.

XduIZBmADRzW9s6ikBvpFA.text: Enjoyed a delicious lunch here. Our hostess/waiter was friendly without being overly attentive. We ordered a pot of the hojicha to start which was fragrant and lovely. We had the grapefruit & hamachi, katsu sandwich, and okonomiyaki. Would recommend the katsu sandwich most out of the three.

Z2sNufG207kDU5FJqNljtw.text: While checking out Heritage Square with my Wife, we came here for an awesome lunch. It was probably some of the best food we have had in awhile. The inside is quaint & comfortable, as it is one of the historic houses that is downtown. Great food, great history, great service. We both fell in love with this hidden gem. Well recommended!

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Dave&#39;s Chicken Katsu Curry &amp; a Short Rib Salad

jStUTsXgpXdeMRdzbu_CwQ.text: I don't just hand out the 5-Star ratings, but this place is well deserving. i travel frequently and while in Phoenix killing time before a delayed flight, I sought out a top tier sushi omakase food experience. What I found instead was an amazing Japanese food experience in an interesting setting.  Interesting setting in a good way rather, in that it's set in a beautiful home with tables and a bar seating setup (which I took advantage of ) and located in a quiet and safe setting with valet parking available adjacent.  As soon as you walk up and inside, it instantly feels like you're transported to another place and time. The hosts and service staff are wonderful and make you feel at home.   Foodwise, I took a ride on their omakase style $100 meal option. The server provided stories on the ingredients and inspiration for each serving that really rounded out the food experience and made it memorable. EVERY single item that came out was not only fun to witness from a presentation perspective, but every bite - and I mean every bit - was absolutely fulfilling.   I enjoyed my dining experience here so much that I made sure to tell all my Phoenix friends about it. This was a great visit and food EXPERIENCE. If you're seeking a True to form Japanese cuisine, don't miss this on your Phoenix food quest.

bofg-VbklEHKOhVXV2t9Kw.text: Loved this place. Not your typical Japanese restaurant and that's why I love it. There are no rolls or rice. It's all tapas style. Very high end unique items. A must try is the miso Foie gras, hamachi grapefruit, and the duck salad was all so amazing. This chef has an exceptional palette. It gets 5 stars in my book

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Prob my most favorite of them all. Warm duck salad. The flavors was amazing and cooked to perfection
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Snap peas was the only thing I was whatever about. The people next to us loved it and recommended it. Bleh
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Echigo beer and the $20 for 6oz sake. Forgot the name. Don&#39;t do either of the $12 for 6oz. They were both terrible

-9kDXrrlq55rQqFajngEDQ.text: Charming ambience.  The food and service was incredible.  The staff was hard working and knowledgable.  Anyone who called this place 'pretentious' or complained about 'small portions' should just stick to eating at Appelbees and Chilis.  You pay for what you get and what you get here is top notch setting, product, and overall experience.  The Grapefruit Harmachi was so money it didn't even know how money it was.

5y2HE1FmrwP32a_ToqfYzw.text: This is quite possibly the best food experience I have ever had in Arizona!  Nobuo can be better described as an culinary experience rather then dining out.  It was almost hard to put into words how much my friends and I enjoyed our meal.  We actually went here by luck.  The dinner party consisted of my two best foodie friends that night.  We had planned to go to Pizzeria Bianco that night after walking around First Fridays.  "Fortunately" the wait that night was over two and a half hours (normally only an hour if you go after 9:30pm).  By chance I saw Nobuo directly across from Pizzeria Bianco so I whipped out my trusty iPhone Yelp AP and proceeded to investigate Nobuo.  The reviews were great so we decided to give it a try.  That my friend was the beginning of my renewed faith in cultured dining in AZ.  We were luckily seated right away that night as it was pretty late already.  The restaurant was cozy and comfortable in a minimalistic classic decor with a few well place Japanese artwork.  We decided to order about 6 dishes from the menu.  2 from the cold dishes side and 4 from the warm side.  1st bite - Grapefruit and Hamachi: This was a very pretty looking dish.  There were 4 spoon servings of delicately prepared Hamachi wrapped around a small slice of grapefruit and avocado with white truffle ponzu oil topped with a sliver of ginger on top.  We each put the bite into our mouths and was transcended to what many would describe as a religious culinary experience.  The flavors literally just burst into your mouth.  Visually you were expecting one thing but the flavor profiles you taste was just simply amazing.  My friends and I looked at each other with the same amazement.  Ok this will be a novel by the time I finish the other 5 courses. I will cut it short by saying it is by far one of the best food experiences I've had in AZ.  Nobuo is not inexpensive, but for this level of quality and experience -  it's worth every cent.

O03h_Dutlz9ROq9FVp9XPg.text: One vegetarian item on the entire dinner menu (an appetizer of snap peas), but the kitchen was willing to make an item from their lunch menu for me: a charred tofu salad with noodles and ginger sauce. It was delicious. Their appetizer of vegetables (hassun I think it's called) has a few things normally fried in beef fat so they were able make substitutions. It was also delicious. The potato flight (an alcohol like vodka) was interesting...definitely worth trying.  We sat outside, which was nicely done with strings of lights and candles. They had wooden benches/tables and then some round tables with metal patio chairs. We sat at the latter and it was very uncomfortable...the round table didn't work well for putting the very large dishes on along with the flight of alcohol, and the chairs were very awkward. There was a seat cushion for the back of the chair but I put the seat cushion on my derriere because it's hard sitting on those waffle-metal chairs after awhile...you end up with a grid on your leg or butt when you get up. Also, because you're eating, you want to sit up--at the table where your plate is--to eat your food and that's very difficult to do in these chairs because they're patio furniture...you're supposed to lean back and relax in them. If you like that while eating dinner, the outside area will work great for you!  Overall, it has cozy but casual feeling, but I wouldn't recommend the outside seating to anyone with a backache or who's planning a more relaxed dinner where they want to sit and enjoy their meal for more than 1/2 an hour.

c5jypI0G8Voa3yq2Z3BzKw.text: Delicious! Contemporary cute decor. I loved the lanterns outside the restaurant. Service was very friendly and food was gourmet delish! The kitchen pays particular attention to presentation. My food was beautiful, smelled wonderful, and tasted fantastic!

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States

LogUOYeYPm7n8gUWm_Ok8w.text: Went last night because Pizza Bianco was a 2 hour wait - at the bar. Was very happy with food. No wasabi needed for whitetail or octopus apps. Totally delicious.  Cool old brick building as well...something not easy to find in downtown Phoenix.

PTAnJZrGA8JLfWfqdP0NOg.text: Great Japanese Tapas and fantastic service as well.  This place was walking distance from my hotel and I wanted to eat something other than sandwiches, pizza, burgers or steaks.    Again service was 5 stars. My server Dillon was almost too concerned with how happy I was.  He gets straight A's.  I had the following Tako (octopus) dumplings : awesome Yellow tail ceviche : too fishy, just meh Coconut curry lamb: amaze balls.  Not gamey at all Apple Fritters with ice cream for dessert:  amaze balls  Great place for families or dates.

vOxXW7XjdvXsy8ASUQyW9w.text: The hamachi was really good...could have 2 orders. The snap peas were fresh. Avocado not bad. The pork belly I probably wouldn't get again, the bread a bit dry and the pork had oil but wasn't fatty? If that could make sense.

KJmyo4x7qyq0SCJsaI6Mfw.text: I am writing an update cause I had the opportunity of sitting on the porch of the restaurant the other night with a companion  cause it was pouring down buckets.    It happened to be First Friday.   We had ridden the light rail downtown to the AZ Science Center and thought we'd walk around to see what, if anything, exciting was going on.   The owner's, Nobuo, wife served us.   I ordered wine and I don't remember what my companion ordered.   Either a beer or wine.    I didn't pay attention.   I believe Nobuo's wife's name is Sarah.   My companion mentioned to her that he had met the owner prior, whereupon Nobuo came out to say "hi," and we had a short chat.    Both are such friendly and charming people.  Very, very gracious and not the typical "full of himself" type of person that I've experienced with other restaurateurs around the valley who are world renowned.

U8HO-BBYSOFJ0ju2KmcViA.text: $16-18 per plate for a tapas style 2 bite plate. The food was average at best.  Horrible service.  Unnecessarily pretentious employees.  $12 drinks.  Did I mention how bad the service was?  PASS

ECa6C47VPTgcLgTTBBr9tA.text: Grapefruit and hamachi...do not miss this one! This is one of the best bites I've ever had. Wish that more of the dinner items were available for lunch! We will be back! Yummy!

z7vn1JuICznRPzEgIWJZpQ.text: OMFG.  DELISH!  Don't miss this hidden gem in downtown Phoenix.   The food is fabulous and the ambiance is darling (tucked away among the high rises in the historic Teeter home across the street from equally charming and not-to-be-missed Pizzeria Bianco).  Nobuo's culinary creations are artfully and beautifully presented.  Each one will have your taste buds BEGGING for more.  Every dish I tasted was, frankly, perfect.    A bite of Nasu (eggplant, bacon, red miso, Tokyo negi) will have you craving another order.  How ON EARTH is eggplant so damn delish???  Grapefruit & Hamachi was light, yet zesty and tasty.   The Big-Eye Tuna Tataki was one of my absolute favorties.  I almost bit the servers arm when she tried to take the plate still smeared with that roast beet puree.  It had the thickness of tomato paste and it was SO GOOD that I wanted to LICK THE PLATE!  I almost ripped the parchment bag keeping us from the Seabass & Mushroom.  The savory broth of garlic-butter, sake and soy will have you fishing for every last solid morsel you can find and searching for a straw to suck up every last drop.  YUMMMMmmmmmm!

-3oJC85yXz4cncL8YVhQLQ.text: If you have never eaten at Nobuo at Teeter House you are missing out on the BEST dining experience in Phoenix! Chef Nobuo, James Beard award winner, delivers an amazing experience with every bite. Tonight my husband and I did the tasting menu: Hassun (Japanese Antipasto), Sashimi spoons, Soft Shell Crab, Saiko Yaki, Chicken Nanban and Pork Belly. Don't walk- RUN to Nobuo at Teeter House! FANTASTIC!!

iZAce6J_Gj4W7RvD4f307A.text: Had the $10 okonomiyaki on a Saturday morning. Hostess was friendly and attentive. Was seated promptly. Okonomiyaki was flavorful with cabbage, pork, shrimp, and bonito flakes. Portion was adequate but probably not justifiable by its price. I would check out their drinks and other items if I had more money... Anyhow, beautiful ambience and use of Teeter's House space. This would be an excellent date or impress your out-of-town-friends spot.

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Okonomiyaki $10

wXv95bmPRBzrAZYkGBDubQ.text: On our recent visit to Phoenix for spring training, we picked this restaurant based on yelp reviews. I'm soo happy the reviews were spot-on!   I absolutely loved this place!  Every dish we had was AMAZING!   Our top 2 favorites were: - grapefruit and hamachi ($14) - seabass and mushroom dish ($14)   We got to sit in the backroom with a coffee table and a couch, which was different from the rest of the restaurant. The ambiance is cozy yet romantic and the service was good too.  If I'm in Phoenix again I'm definitely going back!

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Grapefruit avocado hamachi
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Sea bass

e0sSaUTTxu0QzQ_ZFe8wXA.text: Nobuo's has a beautiful, creative little cocktail menu that I adore. I've eaten here for lunch and dinner, and I absolutely recommend the dinner menu. The Teeter house's dining areas are sectioned off into different rooms, so the atmosphere is intimate and kind of romantic I came to dinner with a party of six and we each ordered three tapas (which are all portioned off to share) and split them among the group over a span of three hours. The dining experience is a constant stream of small portions, but it's relaxing and exciting all at once. I strongly recommend this as a date spot or just a place to take your family out of their comfort zone. My family lived in Japan for five years, and it was so rewarding to bring back some of those tastes and memories for my parents when they visited Phoenix.

nRv33sJxgnXZFOUphToxSw.text: When we first got seated I thought maybe it was a bad choice but looks are deceiving. The service was impeccable. The food was superb.

photos.caption: Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Pork Belly with mushroom rice
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Steamed clams!
Photo of Nobuo At Teeter House - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Yellow Tail ceviche. Delish!

hL84NWiClf12syiXjCSnbA.text: This is a great , intimate, and special gem of a place with fantastic creations from the James Beard award winning chef, Nobuo, in the Heritage Square's Teeter house, a historical old house with hardard floors and simple understated elegance, all in the heart of DT PHX.   In what could be described as Izakaya Fusion small plates, or what one might call "Japa Tapas",  made with attention to detail, flavor and texture, at reasonable prices, this place was part of Phoenix  Yelp's Eats Week recently, with rave reviews from Yelp Foodies.  In a cozy, quiet room with only 4 tables, with dark hardwood floors and minimal decorations, the two of us split the following:  Small Bites Kimchi ($6) - napa cabbage, dried shrimp, seasme oil, red chili.  Instead of the Korean staple fermented and limp, this was fresh cabbage with a lively flavor, crisp and crunchy, as a salad rather than a pickled side dish. Excellent!  Nasu ($8) - eggplant, bacon, red miso, Tokyo negi - this small bacon wrapped morsels stuffed with eggplanbt and akamiso, with shaveed green onions. (8 small pieces) Heavenly!   Others not tried: Shishito Pepper, Watermelon Goat Cheese salad, Tempura Squash Blossom (All $10 or less)  Cold Dishes Yellow Tail Ceviche ($14) - myouga, sesame seed, sherdded taro - a superb blend of textures from the Hamachi to the Taro shavings, caressing the palatte with sultry pleasure (4 pieces)  Tako and Tomato ($16) - fresh grilled octupus, house made mozzarella - like a mini-Italian Caprese appetizer, with half a cherry tomato, a small ball of mozzarella, a touch of basil, and a scored, pounded, grilled tender piece of white octupus! Outrageous yet comforting in its combining recognition with a new ingredient!
